title: Scaling and Enhancing LLM-based AVSR: A Sparse Mixture of Projectors Approach
author: Umberto Cappellazzo (Imperial College London), Minsu Kim (Meta AI), Stavros Petridis (Imperial College London), Daniele Falavigna (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), Alessio Brutti (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), ...
relevance_why: The proposed Sparse Mixture of Projectors (SMoP) approach can enhance audio-visual speech recognition tasks, which could be integrated into Haohe's work on audio processing and generation, especially for achieving robustness in noisy environments.
background: Audio-Visual Speech Recognition (AVSR) integrates visual cues with audio inputs to enhance speech recognition accuracy in noisy environments.
contribution: This paper introduces a Sparse Mixture of Projectors (SMoP) module to enhance the efficiency and performance of multimodal large language models (LLMs) in AVSR, achieving improved accuracy despite using smaller models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in AVSR often relied on large models with high computational costs, compromising deployment in resource-limited settings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by introducing sparsely-gated mixtures of experts that allow smaller LLMs to perform comparably to larger counterparts while reducing inference costs.

key_innovation: Utilizes sparsely-gated expert projectors to scale the model capacity effectively without significant increases in computational costs.
real_world_impact: This research could lead to more accessible and efficient audio-visual speech recognition systems, making technology more applicable in everyday voice-activated applications even in challenging acoustic environments.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Sparse Mixture of Projectors: **Sparse Mixture of Projectors (SMoP)** is a novel technique for embedding multimodal data into language model architectures efficiently, leveraging a limited number of expert layers to optimize performance without proportional increases in computational costs.
